text.76: Akhirnya, Allah menghibur Nabi Muhammad saw dari tingkah laku dan perbuatan kaum kafir dan musyrik itu, yaitu Nabi tidak perlu merasa sedih mendengarkan ucapan dan tuduhan mereka yang bukan-bukan, yang ditujukan kepadanya dan kepada Al-Qur'an. Allah Maha Mengetahui semua perbuatan mereka, baik yang dilakukan dengan terang-terangan maupun yang mereka rahasiakan. Semua itu akan dimintakan pertanggungjawabannya kepada mereka kelak di hari Kiamat dan mereka pasti akan menerima balasannya berupa azab yang pedih.
text.77:
Karena adanya sebagian manusia tidak percaya tentang adanya hari Kebangkitan, maka Pada ayat ini Allah mengingatkan mereka kepada kekuasaan-Nya dalam menciptakan manusia, sebagai bagian dari seluruh makhluk-Nya. Ini dikemukakan dengan nada keheranan atas sikap sebagian manusia itu. Yaitu: apakah manusia itu tidak memikirkan dan tidak memperhatikan bahwa Allah telah menciptakannya dari setetes air mani, tetapi kemudian setelah melalui proses, ia lahir ke dunia dalam bentuk manusia sempurna, kemudian ia menjadi orang yang bersikap memusuhi Allah dan rasul-Nya. Sikap semacam ini benar-benar tidak dapat diterima oleh pikiran yang sehat.

Apabila manusia menyadari bahwa Allah kuasa menciptakannya, bahkan dari setetes air mani, kemudian menjadikan makhluk yang paling baik di bumi ini, pastilah ia yakin, bahwa Allah kuasa pula mengembalikannya kepada asal kejadiannya itu, dan Ia kuasa pula untuk mengulangi kembali penciptaan-Nya, yakni membangkitkannya seperti kehidupannya semula. Oleh karena itu, manusia tidak boleh bersikap melawan perintah Allah.
text.78: Pada ayat ini dijelaskan tentang keraguan kaum kafir Mekah terhadap adanya hari kebangkitan. Mereka berpendapat demikian karena telah melupakan asal kejadian masing-masing. Mereka diingatkan bahwa Allah telah menciptakan mereka dari setetes air mani, sehingga mereka lahir berwujud manusia yang hidup dan utuh. Jika seandainya mereka mengingat dan menyadari hal ini, pastilah mereka yakin bahwa Allah juga kuasa menghidupkannya kembali sesudah mati, walaupun tulang-belulang mereka sudah remuk.
text.79:
Pada ayat ini, Allah memerintahkan Nabi Muhammad saw untuk menjawab pertanyaan orang-orang tersebut di atas, dengan menegaskan bahwa yang akan menghidupkan tulang-tulang lapuk itu kembali menjadi manusia yang hidup dan utuh adalah Allah yang dahulu telah menciptakannya pada kali yang pertama, dari tidak ada menjadi ada. Allah Maha Mengetahui semua makhluk ciptaan-Nya. 

Bagi manusia, mengulang suatu perbuatan lebih mudah daripada melakukannya pertama kali. Akan tetapi, bagi Allah menciptakan sesuatu pertama kali, sama saja mudahnya dengan mengulanginya, karena Allah Mahakuasa.
text.80:
Pada ayat ini disebutkan bahwa Allah juga memerintahkan rasul-Nya untuk menjelaskan kepada orang-orang musyrik tersebut bahwa yang akan menghidupkan kembali tulang-tulang lapuk tersebut adalah Allah yang telah menciptakan untuk mereka, api yang menyala dari kayu yang semula merupakan pohon yang basah dan hijau tetapi kemudian kayu itu menjadi kering sehingga dapat menyalakan api. Dalam kehidupan sehari-hari, orang Arab telah mengetahui bahwa ada beberapa jenis kayu yang jika digesekkan antara satu dengan lainnya akan memercikkan api. Ini semua diciptakan Allah untuk manusia agar mereka bisa menghangatkan badan, memasak, menggunakannya untuk penerangan, dan berbagai kebutuhan lainnya.

Pemberian contoh ini merupakan hal yang cukup jelas bagi mereka yang sehari-hari menggunakan kayu api. Mereka mengira bahwa tulang-tulang yang sudah lapuk itu telah menjadi dingin dan kering tidak dapat lagi menerima kehidupan, sebab kehidupan ini memerlukan adanya panas. Padahal sehari-hari mereka menyaksikan bahwa kayu yang sudah lapuk dan dingin dapat menimbulkan panas dan menghidupkan api. Bahkan kayu yang masih basah dan berdaun ada juga yang dapat menyalakan api.

Menurut kajian ilmiah, api di sini dapat saja diinterpretasikan sebagai energi. Di dalam tumbuhan memang terjadi proses pemanfaatan energi matahari untuk mengubah bahan yang diambil tumbuhan menjadi energi kimiawi. Penjelasan mengenai terjadinya perubahan energi tersebut, yang disebut sebagai proses fotosintesa adalah sebagai berikut.

Dari banyak bagian tumbuhan, salah satu yang terpenting adalah adanya kloroplas (chloroplast) yang terdapat pada daun. Pada kloroplas ini terdapat ribuan kloropil (chlorophyl) atau butir hijau daun, dan dalam bahasa Al-Qur'an dikenal dengan nama al-khadir (bahan hijau). Kedua ayat di atas menyinggung keberadaan kloropil yang berwarna hijau (al-An'am/6: 99) dan peranan matahari dalam menjalankan "pabrik hijau" ini (at-Takwir/81: 17-18).

Sel tumbuhan, tidak sebagaimana sel manusia atau binatang, dapat menggunakan secara langsung energi matahari. Tumbuhan akan mengubah energi matahari menjadi energi kimia, dan menyimpannya dalam bentuk nutrien dengan cara yang khusus. Proses ini dinamakan fotosintesis (Photosynthesis). Sel berwarna hijau ini hanya dapat dilihat dengan menggunakan mikroskop. Ini adalah satu-satunya laboratorium di dunia yang dapat menyimpan energi matahari dalam bentuk bahan organik.

Sebagaimana diuraikan di atas, maka tumbuhan adalah makhluk yang sangat dan paling penting untuk kelangsungan kehidupan makhluk lainnya. Di samping menghasilkan bahan makanan, proses fotosintesa yang dilakukan tumbuhan juga menghasilkan oksigen. Oksigen adalah bahan untuk bernapas bagi semua makhluk hidup, termasuk manusia dan binatang.

Dengan demikian tepatlah Allah memberikan contoh, bahkan bukan hanya kayu yang kering saja dapat menyalakan api tetapi kayu yang masih hijau dan basah pun dapat juga dijadikan kayu api. Sebaliknya, tulang-tulang yang dapat menerima kehidupan bukan hanya tulang-tulang yang segar, tetapi tulang yang sudah lapuk pun dapat pula menerima kehidupan dengan kekuasaan Allah.
text.81: Allah mengemukakan pertanyaan kepada orang-orang yang tidak mempercayai hari kebangkitan itu bahwa jika mereka percaya bahwa Allah kuasa menciptakan langit dan bumi ini, mengapa Allah tidak kuasa pula menciptakan sesuatu yang serupa dengan itu. Jawabannya adalah Allah pasti kuasa menciptakannya, karena Dia Maha Pencipta, lagi Maha Mengetahui.
text.82:
Allah menerangkan betapa mudah bagi-Nya menciptakan sesuatu. Apabila Ia menghendaki untuk menciptakan suatu makhluk, cukuplah Allah berfirman, "Jadilah," maka dengan serta-merta terwujudlah makhluk itu.

Mengingat kekuasaan-Nya yang demikian besar, maka adanya hari kebangkitan itu, di mana manusia dihidupkan-Nya kembali sesudah terjadinya kehancuran di hari Kiamat, bukanlah suatu hal yang mustahil, dan tidak patut diingkari.
text.83:
Orang-orang yang beriman pasti berkata bahwa Allah Mahasuci. Di tangan-Nya kekuasaan penuh atas segala sesuatu di alam ini. Dialah yang menciptakan, mengatur, dan memeliharanya. Kepada-Nya jualah semua makhluk dikembalikan.

Pengakuan dan keyakinan semacam ini pasti timbul apabila manusia menggunakan pikiran sehat untuk memperhatikan isi alam ini semuanya yang menjadi bukti bagi kekuasaan Allah.

en.name: Ya Sin
en.source: Aplikasi Quran Kementrian Agama Republik Indonesia

text.1: In previous surahs, the discussion revolved around the beginnings of surahs that commence with letters of the alphabet. The conclusion reached was that the strongest opinion establishes that these letters of the alphabet are intended as a warning to arouse the interest of the reader in the important matters that will be mentioned in the verses that follow. However, from a narration from Ibn 'Abbas, it is obtained that *ya sin* means *ya insan* (O mankind), that is, O Muhammad. Similarly, is the opinion of Abu Hurairah, 'Ikrimah, adh-Dahhak, Sufyan bin Uyainah, and Sa'id bin Jubair. According to them, *ya sin* originates from the Abyssinian (Ethiopian) language. While Malik, who narrates from Zaid bin Aslam, mentions that the meaning of *ya sin* is an abbreviation of the names of Allah. There is also the opinion that *ya sin* is a summary of the phrase "Ya Sayidal Basyar," that is, the Prophet Muhammad himself. Or it is one of the names of the Al-Qur'an. Nevertheless, the majority of scholars entrust the meaning of *ya sin* to Allah. (For more clarity, see the tafsir of Surah al-Baqarah/2:1)
text.2: Allah swears by the Quran, which is full of wisdom (hikmah). There are several meanings of hikmah derived from the opinions of tafsir scholars, namely: the word "hikmah" here is muhkam, meaning that its truth is certain, and it is impossible for anything false (batil) to be found in it, whether in the meaning of the words (lafadh), purpose, wisdom (hikmah), stories, laws, and so on, from whatever perspective it is viewed. "Hakim" is a characteristic possessed by intelligent people. Similarly, the Quran, with the wisdom (hikmah) it contains, provides humans with the provisions for life to purify their hearts and give spiritual satisfaction. With purity of heart and clarity of mind, the secrets contained in this universe will be revealed. The Quran provides life guidance that is full of wisdom, all its teachings are in line and harmonious with healthy thinking and controlled desires, namely a way of thinking that leads to the benefit of mankind.
text.3: This verse states that the purpose of Allah's oath by the Qur'an, which contains wisdom, is a declaration that Prophet Muhammad is one of Allah's messengers sent to bring the truth. This is a firm rejection of those who do not believe in Muhammad as Allah's messenger.
text.4:
This verse affirms that the Messenger of Allah is on the straight path. This serves as a confirmation that the religion and law brought by the Prophet Muhammad are true, straight, and originate from Allah. One of the characteristics of Muhammad's message is that it is always on the straight path. The truth he brought is clear, without mixing truth and falsehood. The Sharia of Muhammad (peace be upon him) does not tend to follow the desires of human passions, but always encourages people towards happiness, both in this world and in the hereafter. Allah says:

And indeed, [O Muhammad], you guide to a straight path. (ash-Shura/42: 52)
text.5:
This verse firmly establishes the position of the Qur'an, namely, a holy book that originates from Allah, not a holy book composed by humans. Allah has declared to His servants to understand the essence of the holy book He has revealed, which is from the All-Powerful, who acts as He wills, but He is also the Most Merciful to His servants. That mercy is embodied in the Qur'an, which contains mercy for all mankind.

A similar meaning to this verse is:

And indeed, this (Qur'an) is a revelation from the Lord of the worlds. (ash-Shu'ara'/26: 192)
text.6:
As for the wisdom behind the revelation of the Qur'an, it includes giving a warning to the Arab people to whom a messenger had never been sent. This verse mentions the moral corruption of the Arab people due to the heedless nature of their hearts. A heedless heart is a heart that does not fulfill the obligations that must be fulfilled. They were the Arab people, descendants of Prophet Ismail, to whom no messenger had ever been sent. Therefore, they did not know the sharia that leads people to happiness in this world and the hereafter. As for the word *qaum*, which contains a specific meaning directed only at the Arab people, it does not change the actual intent of the message, which is directed to all of humanity, as affirmed in another verse:

Say, "O mankind, indeed I am the Messenger of Allah to you all..." (al-A'raf/7: 158)
text.7: It has become Allah's decree to punish the ancestors of the disbelievers, just as happened to most communities that rejected the arrival of the messengers sent to them. Their denial and moral depravity caused their hearts to be unable to appreciate the truth and unwilling to submit to Allah.
text.8:
Then, an analogy is given for those who do not want to believe, as if shackles have been placed on their necks, their hands raised up to their chins. This causes their faces to always be upturned. Such is the depiction of those who do not believe because they cannot turn to the right or left to make comparisons. The shackles are so tight that their heads cannot move at all. In another verse, there is also the following explanation:

"And if the truth had followed their desires, surely the heavens and the earth would have been ruined, and all that is within them. But We have given them their reminder, but they turn away from their reminder." (al-Mu'minun/23: 71)

According to a narration, this verse was initially revealed in connection with the intention of Abu Jahal and two of his friends from Bani Makhzum. Abu Jahal had sworn that if he saw Muhammad praying at the Baitullah (Kaaba), he would drop a large stone on his head. One day, he saw the Prophet (peace be upon him) prostrating, with a large enough stone in his hand. When he lifted the stone and was about to throw it at the Prophet (peace be upon him) who was prostrating, he hesitated and the stone slipped from his grasp. Abu Jahal returned to his people and told them what had happened.

Then, another member of Bani Makhzum, intrigued by Abu Jahal's story, also intended to throw a stone at the Prophet (peace be upon him) while he was about to pray. When he was about to carry out his evil intention, Allah blinded his eyes. He returned to his people in a state of blindness. He recounted that when he was about to carry out his intention, a large animal suddenly appeared, ready to pounce on him. If he had thrown the stone, the animal would have certainly attacked him. Some say that the meaning of shackles here is a metaphorical meaning (majazi). So, what is meant by shackles is an obstacle that prevents a person's intention to believe in Allah.
text.9:
It is also described that those who do not believe see the evil deeds they commit as good. This causes them to become arrogant, so they are reluctant to follow the teachings of the Messenger. Their minds are closed to the truth, to what can bring benefit. Therefore, they can only understand what has been inherited from their ancestors. In short, they are always in a prison of ignorance, as if their hearts are separated by a wall, so they cannot think and contemplate the proofs of the truth of the teachings brought by the Messenger.

Some also interpret the obstructing wall as a hijab; thus meaning that Allah has placed a hijab that prevents the polytheists from harming the Messenger. The closed eyes are interpreted as meaning that they cannot properly perceive what they see, and no guidance can straighten their minds.

(10) In this verse, Allah explains that those who cannot accept guidance will not change even if threatened with severe punishment. This is because their hearts are actually sealed and cannot accept guidance. This is because their minds are no longer able to think about the truth that is conveyed, and their eyes are blind to that truth. In short, whoever Allah has decreed to be astray, no advice given to them will benefit them. Allah says:

Indeed, those who disbelieve - it is all the same for them whether you warn them or do not warn them - they will not believe. Allah has set a seal upon their hearts and upon their hearing, and over their vision is a veil. And for them is a great punishment. (al-Baqarah/2: 6-7)

And His saying:

Indeed, those upon whom the word of your Lord has been justified will not believe. (Yunus/10: 96)
text.10:
In this verse, Allah explains that those who cannot accept guidance, even when threatened with severe punishment, will not change. This is because their hearts are essentially sealed shut and unable to receive guidance. This is due to their minds no longer being able to contemplate the truth that is conveyed, and their eyes being blind to that truth. In short, whoever Allah has decreed to be astray will not benefit from any advice given to them. Allah says:

Indeed, those who disbelieve - it is all the same for them whether you warn them or do not warn them - they will not believe. Allah has set a seal upon their hearts and their hearing, and over their eyes is a veil. And for them is a great punishment. (al-Baqarah/2: 6-7)

And His saying:

Indeed, those upon whom the word of your Lord has been justified will not believe. (Yunus/10: 96)
text.11:
In this verse, Allah explains that only those who can receive the guidance of the Prophet Muhammad are those who fear hearing Allah's threats, namely those who believe in the Qur'an and are willing to implement the guidelines that have been outlined. They feel aware, apprehensive, and horrified when they hear Allah's threats and punishments. Allah is the Greatest in His mercy and the Most Severe in His punishment, as mentioned in another verse:

"Inform My servants that it is I who am the Forgiving, the Merciful, and that My punishment is indeed the most painful punishment." (al-Hijr/15: 49-50)

Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad to give good news to those who believe that they will receive *magfirah* (forgiveness) and a noble reward, namely eternal blessings that cannot be described, never seen by the eye, heard by the ear, or conceived in the heart. Another verse states:

"Indeed, those who fear their Lord unseen will have forgiveness and a great reward." (al-Mulk/67: 12)

The meaning of Allah's statement "fear their Lord unseen" is to always carry out His commands and avoid His prohibitions whether or not anyone knows, or to be pious to Allah whether they are alone or with others. It is people of faith and such character that Allah gives good news through the Prophet Muhammad. The good news is that all the sins they have ever committed will be forgiven by Allah with His *magfirah*, and they will enjoy a noble reward, namely a paradise as vast as the heavens and the earth, as stated in the verse:

"And hasten to forgiveness from your Lord and to a garden as wide as the heavens and earth, prepared for the righteous." (ali 'Imran/3: 133)
text.12:
Then it is also mentioned that one must fear their Lord, because Allah will resurrect all those who have died and raise them from their respective graves on the Day of Judgment. At that time, humans will receive a record of all their deeds, both big and small, that they had done in the world. Not a single deed will escape the record. Everything is written in the book meticulously. The Qur'an states:

And the record [of deeds] will be placed [open], and you will see the criminals fearful of that within it, and they will say, "Oh, woe to us! What is this record that leaves nothing small or great except that it has enumerated it?" And they will find what they did present [before them]. And your Lord does injustice to no one. (al-Kahf/18: 49)

Not only are their deeds written in that book, but also all the good deeds they left behind, which are followed and still utilized by many people after their death, such as the knowledge they taught, the property they endowed, or the hospital they built for public health. Similarly, the evil deeds they left behind, such as the slander they spread that caused people to disagree or become divided. In short, every action that has an impact, whether beneficial or harmful, is written in that book. This verse is in line with the hadith of the Prophet Muhammad which states: "Whoever initiates a good tradition (custom) will have its reward and the reward of those who practice it after his death without diminishing their reward in the slightest. And whoever initiates a bad tradition (custom) will bear its sin and the sin of those who practice it after (his) death without diminishing their sin in the slightest." Then the Prophet Muhammad recited the verse "wanaktubu maqaddamu wa atsarahum" (and We record what they have put forth and what they left behind). (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Abu Musa al-Asy'ari)

Regarding the meaning of Allah's statement "And We record what they have put forth and what they left behind," Imam at-Tirmidzi narrated a story, as included by Ibn Kathir in his tafsir, in which it was told that there were people from Bani Salamah who lived on the outskirts of Medina. They felt how far their homes were from the Prophet's mosque. In order to be able to come to the congregational prayer earlier to obtain the virtue of praying in congregation, they intended to move their homes to the area around the mosque, so this verse was revealed. After the Prophet Muhammad called them, he said, "Your good intention will be written." In the end, they did not move.

Ibn Jarir ath-Thabari also narrated that the homes of some of the Ansar were far from the Prophet Muhammad's mosque. They wanted to move them, so this verse was revealed. They eventually canceled their intention. Perhaps what prompted the people of Bani Salamah or a group of the Ansar companions to move their homes was the hadith of the Prophet Muhammad which stated that praying in congregation is 27 times more rewarding than praying alone.

The Prophet Muhammad said:

"The people who will get the greatest reward in prayer are those who live farthest away and then those who live next farthest, and a person who waits for the prayer so as to pray it along with the Imam, will have a greater reward than a person who prays and then sleeps." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Musa)

Then it is further emphasized that not only are the deeds of Bani Adam written in that book meticulously, but also what happens on this earth. According to the explanation of the scholars of tafsir, what is meant by *Imamum Mubin* (a clear record) is *Lauh Mahfudh*. This verse is further strengthened by the explanation of other verses which state:

[Moses] said, "Knowledge thereof is with my Lord in a record. My Lord neither errs nor forgets." (thaha/20: 52)

And the verse:

And every small and great thing is written down. (al-Qamar/54: 53)

Such is the explanation of the verses above which confirm the coming of the Day of Judgment, where humans will receive recompense for all their efforts, both evil and good. From this verse, it can be understood that the good news of forgiveness and paradise for those who are pious to God and follow the guidance of the Qur'an is determined by Allah later after the Day of Resurrection.
text.13:
Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad to relate to the polytheistic Quraysh, and also to those who denied his message, the story of Ashhabul Qaryah (the People of the City) as a lesson for them. The essence of the story states that whoever denies the messengers will experience a misfortune like what was experienced by Ashhabul Qaryah. In some tafsir (Quranic commentaries) it is explained that what is meant by Ashhabul Qaryah is the inhabitants of the city of Antioch (Arabic: Anthakiyah), but some mention the inhabitants of an unknown city.

As for the three messengers, some mention that they were the messengers of Isa (Jesus) to the inhabitants of that land, and others mention that they were messengers sent to the inhabitants of that land.
text.14: Because the two messengers, some say named (Yuhana and Bulus), did not succeed in carrying out their mission, another person named Syam'un was sent with the same task. The message they carried was for the people of Antioch to cleanse themselves of shirk, to free themselves from all forms of worship other than Allah, and then to return to the teachings of tawhid.
text.15:
Then, in this verse, the fundamental reason why his people refused to believe in Allah is mentioned. Most of those who denied the messengers believed that the three messengers were just ordinary people like themselves, without any outstanding distinction. At that time, and perhaps even now, a person would not be respected if they did not possess extraordinary intelligence or skills.

The second reason was because they were convinced that the Most Gracious (ar-Rahman) had not sent down any message or book containing revelation, nor had He commanded them to believe in the three messengers. Therefore, they concluded that the three messengers were complete liars. Allah's statement describing their rejection, "ma anzala ar-rahman," indicates that the people of Antioch had long known God, only they denied Him and replaced Him with idols. Therefore, they rejected all the messengers.
text.16:
Such a view was refuted by the messengers, saying that only Allah knows that they are truly the ones sent to those people. If they were lying, then a painful punishment would befall them. Their mission would be pleasing to Allah, and it would surely be known later who was at fault and had to bear the risk for that fault. In another verse, such an answer can indeed be uttered by a messenger, for example:

And they ask you to hasten the punishment. And if it were not for a specified term, the punishment would have come to them. But it will surely come to them suddenly while they do not perceive. (al-'Ankabut/29: 53)
text.17: This verse explains that the mission brought by the messengers was merely to convey Allah's message. The decision is in the hands of mankind, whether to believe in that message or not. If they believe, the benefit of that belief is for their own happiness, both in this world and the hereafter. Conversely, if those disbelievers do not want to carry out the call of the messengers, then the consequences will certainly befall themselves.
text.18:
In this verse, it is explained that the people of Antioch could no longer refute the arguments of the messengers. Therefore, they threatened, saying that if misfortune befell them in the future, it would be due to the actions of these three men. Thus, if the messengers did not want to stop this futile preaching, they would be forced to stone them or inflict a very painful punishment. The three messengers countered their words by saying that if the people of Antioch were forced to experience punishment in the future, it would be a result of their own actions. Were they not the ones who associated partners with Allah, committed acts of disobedience, and made mistakes? While the three messengers were only inviting them to affirm the Oneness of Allah (Tawhid), to be sincere in worship, and to repent from all their sins. Was it because the messengers warned them of Allah's severe punishment and invited them to acknowledge His Oneness that they would then punish the messengers? Was that the appropriate reward for the messengers? This shows that they were a nation that transgressed the limits in their way of thinking and in deciding to punish and stone the messengers. They considered evil those who should have been the ones from whom they sought guidance. A verse with a similar meaning to this verse is:

"Then when good (prosperity) came to them, they said, "This is ours (by right)." But if evil afflicted them, they attributed it to Moses and those with him. Unquestionably, their fortune is with Allah, but most of them do not know." (al-A'raf/7: 131)
text.19:
In this verse, it is explained that the people of Antioch could no longer refute the arguments of the messengers. Therefore, they threatened, saying that if misfortune befell them in the future, it would be due to the actions of these three men. Thus, if the messengers did not want to stop this futile preaching, they would be forced to stone them or inflict a most painful punishment. The three messengers countered their words by saying that if the people of Antioch were forced to experience punishment in the future, it would be a result of their own actions. Were they not the ones who associated partners with Allah, committed acts of disobedience, and made mistakes? While the three messengers were only inviting them to affirm the oneness of Allah (tawhid), to purify themselves in worship, and to repent from all their errors. Was it because the messengers warned them of Allah's severe punishment and invited them to acknowledge His oneness that they would then punish the messengers? Was that the appropriate reward for the messengers? This shows that they were a nation that transgressed the limits in their way of thinking and in making decisions to punish and stone the messengers. They considered evil those who should have been the ones from whom they sought guidance. A verse with a similar meaning to this verse is:

"Then when good (prosperity) came to them, they said, "This is ours (by right)." But if evil afflicted them, they attributed it to Moses and those with him. Unquestionably, their fortune is with Allah, but most of them do not know." (al-A'raf/7: 131)
text.20: This verse explains that it is *sunnatullah* (Allah's established way) that when a messenger tasked with conveying the truth is under pressure, they will certainly receive Allah's help. Related to the story of the people of Antioch's rejection of the three messengers of Prophet Isa (Jesus), came a man named Habib an-Najjar who had no influence or decisive power, nor was he a family member or person influential with the king of that land. It was only with the dynamics of the strength of his faith that he came from the remote parts of the land to defend the three messengers by warning the people who intended to torture them. He called on the people of the city to follow the messengers who came only to convey Allah's guidance.
text.21:
The man explained that the three messengers who preached the truth did not expect any reward at all for their efforts in conveying the message. They received guidance from Allah that what should be worshipped is Allah, the One and Only, without associating anything with Him.

The man named Habib an-Najjar came from afar to explain to the people of Antioch that he was giving them lessons and teachings, after he was convinced that what he conveyed was something good for himself and them. Why should he not worship Allah, the One and Only, who created him, and to whom all living things will return? There they will receive all the rewards for their deeds. Those who do good will surely enjoy the results of their goodness, while those who do evil will certainly not be able to escape punishment as retribution. The above affirmation is in response to the question of his people who refused to believe.

According to Habib, it is not appropriate for him to seek other gods besides the One and Only God. The gods they worship are gods who cannot give benefit or ward off harm, do not hear and see, and cannot give help (syafaat). These gods certainly cannot save them from Allah's torment, even if they have worshipped them. Therefore, if he participates in worshipping what they worship besides the One and Only God, surely he has taken a path of error. If he worships statues made of stone or other creatures, which are completely impossible to bring benefit or ward off harm, doesn't that mean he is already in error?

The man who came from afar ended his advice by affirming before his people to the three messengers about his true stance. He said, "Listen, O messengers of Prophet Isa, I believe in your Lord who sent you. Therefore, witness and listen to what I say."

According to a narration, after Habib proclaimed his stance, the disbelieving people then stoned him. His whole body was bleeding. Finally, Habib died as a martyr upholding the truth. There is also a narration that says that his two legs were pulled in opposite directions until they were torn, so that fresh blood spurted from his anus. He fell while carrying out his duty. Before meeting his death, the hero still had time to pray to Allah, "O Allah, guide my people, indeed they are people who do not know."

When the Day of Resurrection arrives, Allah commands Habib, "Enter into Paradise as a reward for what you have done during your life in the world." After he entered and felt how beautiful and pleasant Allah's reward is for those who believe and are patient in carrying out the task of da'wah, he said, "I wish my people knew that I obtained forgiveness and glory from Allah." Magfirah and glory that can only be enjoyed by some people who believe.

Indeed, the verse above uses the word "tamanni" (hoping for something impossible to achieve) to encourage the people of Antioch and the believers in general to strive as much as possible to obtain such rewards, repent from all disbelief, and enter into the group of people who feel the beauty of believing in Allah, obeying the path of Allah's saints, by restraining anger and bestowing love on those who oppose them.

Ibn 'Abbas said that Habib advised his people when he was still alive with the words, "Follow the message brought by the messengers." Then after dying as a result of their torture, he also still hoped, "I wish my people knew that Allah has forgiven me and made me among those who are glorified." After Habib was killed, Allah sent down His punishment upon them. Jibril was ordered to come to the rebellious people. With just one shout, as loud as thunder, they suddenly all died. That was a fitting reward for the mistake of denying Allah's messengers, killing His saints, and denying Allah's message.
text.22:
In this verse, the awareness that arises in the heart and the light of faith that has illuminated the soul of that person are described, so that he believes that there is no reason whatsoever for him not to believe in Allah. Because He is the One who created and shaped him in such a way in the process of creation, making it possible for him to embrace the religion of *tauhid*, which is the religion that teaches to believe in Allah as the One and Only God.

At the end of this verse, that person declares that only to Allah will he return after leaving this fleeting worldly life, not to anyone else. This statement arises from the depths of his heart, after he has felt the power and greatness of Allah.

A person submits himself to Allah because:

1.  He feels the power and greatness of Allah. Only He is entitled to be worshipped, nothing else. Because of that belief, he continues to submit himself to Allah in whatever state he is in, whether he is given blessings by Him or not, whether he is in misery or in pleasure, whether in hardship or ease.

2.  A servant who worships Allah has felt the blessings bestowed upon him, he feels dependent on those blessings of Allah.

3.  A servant hopes for reward from Allah and fears being afflicted by His punishment.

The servant referred to in this verse is the servant who belongs to the first category. That servant continues to worship Allah in accordance with what He has decreed, even if he is afflicted by disaster, misery, and other trials. He declares that everything he has, his soul and body, his life and death, all belong to Allah.

This person's faith is in accordance with the faith mentioned in Allah's word:

Say, "Indeed, my prayer, my rites of sacrifice, my living and my dying are for Allah, Lord of the worlds. No partner has He. And this I have been commanded, and I am the first [among you] of the Muslims." (al-An'am/6: 162-163)
text.23: Furthermore, the servant mentioned above asked himself, "Should I worship a god other than Allah, the One and Only, when if He intended to inflict some calamity or harm upon me, surely nothing could help me, nor could the gods I worship. They have no power whatsoever to save me from harm and calamity."
text.24: Furthermore, the servant mentioned above asked himself, "Should I worship a god other than Allah, the One and Only, when if He intended to inflict some calamity or harm upon me, surely nothing could help me, including the gods I worship. They are powerless to save me from harm and calamity."
text.25: He then obtained the correct answer to that question, which is that it is not at all fitting for him to worship other than Allah. Only Allah is the true Lord. And if he were to worship other than Allah, he would surely be in manifest error.
text.26:
Finally, the person made the right decision based on a full conviction that he only believed in Allah, who is the true Lord for him and his people. He then announced his faith and conviction to his people, and said firmly, "Indeed, I have believed in Allah, who is your true Lord. So listen to this declaration of my faith."

Such an attitude and declaration of faith, uttered in the midst of a society still steeped in disbelief, polytheism, and immorality, truly represents courage arising from the light of faith that has illuminated his conscience. He wanted his people to believe as well. He was not afraid of threats that endangered him, in order to carry out the sacred duty of inviting people to the right path.

According to a narration, when that person said this, his people attacked and killed him, and no one defended him.

According to Qatadah, "His people stoned him, and he kept praying, 'O my Lord, guide my people, for they do not know.'" They stoned him until he breathed his last. In another narration, it is mentioned that the person referred to in the verses above was named Habib an-Najjar, who suffered from measles but liked to give charity. Half of his daily income was given to charity. It is mentioned that after his people heard his declaration of faith in Islam, their anger flared up against him, and they finally killed him. However, in the moments before he breathed his last, an angel descended upon him to inform him that Allah had forgiven all his sins that he had committed before he believed, and he was admitted into Paradise, thus becoming one of those who received honor in the sight of Allah.

In his last moments, he still managed to utter words containing hope, "Oh, if only my people knew the grace of Allah bestowed upon me, thanks to my faith in Him, I have obtained forgiveness for my sins. I will be admitted into Paradise with manifold rewards, and be among those who obtain honor in His sight. If only they knew this, surely they would believe as well."

Habib's statement is a statement of immense value and demonstrates the loftiness of his character. Even though he had been stoned and tortured by his people, he still hoped that his people would realize and receive mercy from the Lord as he had experienced.

text.29: In this verse, Allah explains the punishment inflicted upon the polytheistic, disbelieving, and those who deny His religion. Allah did not need to send down armies of angels to destroy them; rather, a single cry from the angel Gabriel was sufficient to render those disbelievers stiff and lifeless. This event occurred so quickly, as proof of the magnitude of Allah's power.
text.30: Allah explains that the attitude and behavior of the disbelievers like this is deeply regrettable. They not only reject the call to faith, but also mock the messengers and those who have believed. Indeed, it is not uncommon for them to persecute and kill them. If they were willing to think with a sound mind, they would surely accept the call to faith from the messengers and those who have believed. Allah explains the position of the disbelievers in the Hereafter when they are afflicted with a terrible torment for denying the messengers.
text.31:
Allah then warned them to pay attention to the fate that befell the disbelieving people centuries before them, who had been struck by Allah's wrath, so that they were destroyed and vanished from the face of the earth. They will never reappear in this world.

Ibn Kathir said, "Most of the Salaf scholars narrate that what is meant by 'the city' in this verse is the city of Antioch, and those who were sent were the messengers of Prophet Isa, to that city to convey his message."

There are several things that make us reluctant to accept this narration due to the following factors:

1. It is impossible for Allah to destroy the city of Antioch because the inhabitants of that city were the first people to believe in Isa. Allah would not destroy a city whose inhabitants were believing and fulfilling the call of the messenger sent to them.

2. In this verse, it is explained that the city was destroyed by Allah, so that the entire city and its inhabitants were annihilated. The Qur'an explains that Allah sent down punishment upon the disbelievers in the form of destruction and annihilation of them along with their cities, until the Torah was revealed. After the Torah was revealed, Allah never sent down such punishment.

This is understood from His saying:

And We had already given Moses the Scripture after We destroyed the former generations as enlightenment for the people and guidance and mercy that they might be reminded. (al-Qashash/28: 43)

3. There is no strong *nash* (textual evidence) related to that narration, such as information explaining when and where the event occurred, and so on.

Meanwhile, Muslims believe in the stories contained in the Qur'an. Not all stories are explained in detail by the Qur'an. Some stories are explained in detail and some are not. However, each story has a purpose and objective. Therefore, Muslims do not need to know the details of the story mentioned in the verse above. However, Muslims should make these stories a lesson and *iktibar* (admonition), so that they can increase and strengthen their respective faith.
text.32: In this verse, Allah affirms that all of them, whether those who came before, those who are present, or those who will come in the future, will certainly be gathered before Him to account for their deeds and behavior during their time in the world.
text.33: This verse explains that one of the signs of Allah's power and the existence of the Day of Resurrection is the existence of land that was initially dead, barren, and arid, and did not grow any plants. However, with Allah's power, it all comes to life with the descent of rain from the sky. This allows for the growth of various plants that produce food for humans and other creatures living on this earth. Thus, humans and creatures obtain food to grow their bodies and give them strength. In addition to that, these earth's products can also be used as trading materials to be traded by humans.
text.34: Allah also created on this earth gardens, fields, and rice paddies, which can be planted with various kinds of plants that produce food for humans, such as dates and grapes which are staple foods for the Arab people. Likewise, rice, wheat, and corn which are staple foods for other nations. In addition to that, Allah created water sources that then flow into rivers, which are very necessary for life on earth. Even in our time now, water is not only needed for drinking, bathing, and washing, but also for irrigation and generating electricity which is very important for advancing agriculture and industry.
text.35: Allah created and bestowed all of that upon mankind, so that they may obtain sustenance from the fruits and produce. Likewise, from the results of their handicraft efforts, which we now know as the agricultural and industrial products that are almost countless in number. If they would only reflect on how immense Allah's power and blessings are, why would they not be grateful to Him? Such an attitude and behavior is truly unbecoming of people of intellect.
text.36:
In this verse, another proof of Allah's power is explained: that He has created His creatures in pairs, both pairs of species, namely male and female, and pairs of characteristics, such as: big and small, strong and weak, high and low, rich and poor, and so on.

Even pairing occurs in electric current, namely positive and negative currents, which then create a force that can generate electricity and produce light. The electricity and light produced are very vital in the lives of modern humans.

These are all things that humans have managed to discover up to the present time. However, there are still many pairings that have not been reached by human knowledge and discoveries to this day. It is possible that advances in human science and technology in the future will also be able to reveal some of the secrets that are still hidden about the existence of pairings in other fields that are not yet known in our time.

In this verse, signs of Allah's power and greatness are explained, which are found in the pairs that He has created, namely:

1. Things that He grows on earth that are known to humans, such as plants and so on.

2. In themselves, such as the existence of male and female types. From the relationship between these two types, their descendants are born.

3. Things that humans do not yet know. Allah's knowledge is vast and infinite, while what humans know is only a small part. Regarding pairs, there are also things that have not been revealed by humans.
text.37:
In this verse, Allah explains another proof of His Great Power and evidence of the Day of Resurrection, which is the existence of night. Allah removes the day and brings the night, and suddenly people are in darkness.

This verse lays the foundations for natural sciences and astronomy. The occurrence of day and night is due to the movement of the solar system, especially the earth and the sun, so that the part of the earth exposed to sunlight experiences day, and the part not exposed to sunlight experiences night. This happens alternately.

The advancement of human knowledge in astronomy in modern times has enabled them to know the objects in outer space. With technological advancements, humans can finally navigate outer space, not just observe it from Earth.

The existence of day and night is also beneficial for humans. They use the daytime to work for their livelihood. While nighttime is generally used for rest and sleep, as one of their physical and spiritual needs.
text.38:
Allah explains another proof of His power, which is the movement of the sun, which moves in its specific orbit in an orderly manner according to the provisions that Allah has established. It does not deviate even slightly from the line that has been determined. If it were to deviate by even a hair's breadth, there would inevitably be a collision with other celestial bodies. We cannot imagine what would happen as a result of that event.

At first glance, one would accept that only the sun moves, while the earth remains in its place. In the morning, the sun is seen in the east, while in the afternoon it is in the west. However, astronomy says that the sun travels while rotating on its axis, while the earth is in front of it, also traveling while rotating on its axis, and orbiting the sun.

It turns out that what is determined by astronomy is in line with what has been explained in the verse. Therefore, it is not an exaggeration to say that the higher the ability of human science and technology, the more open the truths that the Qur'an has put forward since fourteen centuries ago. Allahu Akbar. Allah is the Greatest in His power.
text.39:
Allah has determined specific distances for the moon's orbit, so that at each distance it undergoes changes, both in its shape and size, as well as in the strength of its light. Initially, the moon appears small and with weak light. Then it becomes a crescent moon with a curved shape and increasingly bright light. Furthermore, its shape becomes more perfectly round, until it becomes a full moon with very bright light. But then it shrinks again, until finally it resembles a dry palm stalk, curved in shape with increasingly fading light, returning to its original state.

If we also observe the other celestial bodies, which are billions in number, with different distances and sizes, as well as different speeds of movement, all moving in an orderly and neat manner, all of that will increase our conviction about the unlimited space of this universe and how great is the power of Allah who created and regulates His creation.

By observing all of that, there will be no other words that come out of the mouth of a believer, other than the utterance "Allahu Akbar, Allah is the Greatest, and how Great is His power."
text.40:
Based on Allah's arrangement and decree that applies to natural objects, a rule called "Sunnatullah," it is impossible for the sun and moon to collide, nor can night precede day. Everything will proceed according to the regulations He has established. Each continues to move according to the orbit Allah has determined for it.

How small is the power of humans compared to the power of Allah who creates and regulates the movement of natural objects so that they continue to run in an orderly manner. Humans have made various traffic regulations on the highway equipped with diverse signs. However, traffic accidents on the highway still occur everywhere. Human regulations always show their weaknesses.
text.41:
In this verse, Allah states that ships sailing in the middle of the ocean are one of the proofs of His greatness and power. These ships transport people and their necessities from one country to another, whether they are located close to each other or far apart.

The use of marine transportation as a means of communication utilized by humans to move and transport goods has been known since ancient times, even since the time of Prophet Noah. The first person to build a ship was Prophet Noah. The ship was built upon Allah's command and guidance. This is explained in His word:

"And construct the ship under Our observation and Our inspiration..." (Hud/11: 37)

Boats, canoes, and heavy-tonnage ships, whether powered by human labor, wind power, or engine power, can glide easily on the water, transporting people and goods from one island to another, from one continent to another. This is certainly related to a force that holds the ship, preventing it from sinking. This is evidence of Allah's power and greatness through the implementation of His natural laws.

Allah says:

"Do you not see that ships sail through the sea by the favor of Allah that He may show you of His signs? Indeed in that are signs for everyone patient and grateful." (Luqman/31: 31)
text.42:
In this verse, Allah reminds mankind of another proof of His power. Allah provides mankind with various vehicles besides boats, arks, and ships, namely animals that can be used as vehicles or means of transportation, such as horses, donkeys, camels, elephants, and so on. These are land transportation for humans.

In another verse, Allah says:

"And (He has created) horses, mules, and donkeys for you to ride and (as) adornment. And Allah creates what you do not know." (an-Nahl/16: 8)

To enable the transportation of more people and goods, humans can make land transportation tools pulled by these animals, such as horse-drawn carriages, carts, wagons, and so on. By using the intellect that Allah has bestowed upon them, humans can also make transportation tools that move with engine power using fuel in the form of petroleum or coal, which Allah also provides and bestows upon mankind. These motorized vehicles can travel faster and carry more loads.

Thanks to the advancement of reason (logic) and knowledge that Allah has bestowed upon mankind, they can make vehicles that can fly in the air, from balloons, airplanes, to rockets that propel spacecraft that can exceed the speed of sound. All of that is a blessing from Allah to mankind. By circumventing the law of gravity, humans have succeeded in creating airplanes for the benefit of human transportation.
text.43:
Allah warns that if He willed to sink the ships sailing on the seas, it would surely happen. The arrival of strong storm winds that create tremendous waves would cause the ships to sink, their passengers to perish and be buried at the bottom of the sea, beyond rescue.

This is a warning so that humans do not become arrogant, conceited, and feel that their achievements in creating vehicles that can travel on land, sea, and air are solely due to their intellectual prowess, and not because of Allah's grace.

From natural science, we can understand that something can float on water if its specific gravity is lighter than the specific gravity of the water it passes through. This is the provision or *sunnatullah* that Allah has established for the water He created. By manipulating the natural law about water that can cause an object to sink and also float, humans can create submarines that can dive deep into the seabed, but when needed, can rise to the surface of the water. This is done by reducing the air in the submarine's cavity, causing it to sink. However, if air is pumped back into the cavity, the submarine will become lighter so that it can float on the surface of the water.
text.44: In this verse, Allah affirms that because of His immense compassion for His servants, and so that they may enjoy His blessings, Allah does not allow all those vehicles to perish, whether they travel on land, sail on the surface and in the water, or fly in the air. Especially if those who use the vehicles are not arrogant and are always careful and cautious. If an accident occurs at any time, it is because the person concerned was not careful, was less meticulous, negligent, or for other reasons.
text.45:
Allah explains that even if those who disbelieve were urged to guard themselves against Allah's punishment that will come later, they would still turn away, unwilling to listen to the exhortation. Yet, the exhortation is conveyed so that they may receive mercy from Allah.

Guarding oneself from Allah's punishment is by having taqwa towards Him, which is by doing what He commands, avoiding all that He forbids, and being grateful for every blessing He bestows. However, the hearts of those who disbelieve have been sealed against the truth. They constantly turn away from good advice. Therefore, it is fitting that they are afflicted by Allah's wrath and punishment.
text.46: Allah affirms that those who disbelieve are constantly turning away from every sign that demonstrates His Oneness and Power, as well as acknowledging the prophethood of His messenger. Their hearts have become blind, even though their physical eyes can clearly see all of these signs.
text.47:
Allah mentions another aspect of their denial, which is their reluctance to donate a portion of the wealth He has bestowed upon them. When they are encouraged to spend their wealth for the benefit of the poor and needy, they reply to the believers who encourage them, "Why should we feed them, since Allah can feed them if Allah wills." In addition to that, they say that the believers who like to donate wealth to help the poor are misguided and foolish people.

How far their opinion is from the truth. Donating a portion of wealth and helping others in the form of obligatory donations, such as zakat, as well as voluntary donations, such as sadaqah, is a manifestation of faith and gratitude for Allah's blessings, and at the same time eliminates the trait of stinginess from the human soul. According to Islamic teachings, wealth has a social function, not just for personal interests.

Wealth must be used as a tool to strengthen the bonds of brotherhood, solidarity, and mutual cooperation. Humans cannot live alone, without expecting help from others in various necessities of life, even if they are very wealthy.
text.48: Another aspect of the ugly characteristics of the disbelieving people is their disbelief in the Day of Resurrection after death. When it is conveyed that they will be resurrected after death to account for their deeds during their time in this world, they respond with mockery, "When will that promise be fulfilled?" Such is the state of the disbelieving people; their hearts are no longer open to receiving the truth. Their regret will only arise after they face the reality of what they used to deny.
text.49:
Allah warns that they will not have to wait too long for the coming of the Day of Resurrection. It will be enough with a single command shout, namely the first trumpet blast that brings about the destruction of this universe. Then all humans will be resurrected and gathered before Allah to be reckoned for all their deeds while on earth, and then they will receive recompense according to their deeds.

Another verse with the same meaning as this verse is the word of Allah:

"Do they then await anything except that the Hour should come upon them suddenly while they perceive not?" (az-Zukhruf/43: 66)

Humans will not realize the coming of the Day of Resurrection. They will die suddenly while in a state of disagreement and arguing about worldly matters. The event of the Day of Resurrection or death occurs suddenly because both do not occur as a result of a compromise between Allah and humans, but because of Allah's will and power alone.

It is narrated by Ibn Jarir ath-Thabari from Ibn 'Umar that he said, "The trumpet will indeed be blown when people are busy with their respective affairs in the streets, markets, and their places, to the point that two people are bargaining over clothes, for example, when the clothes have not yet reached the hands of one of them, suddenly the trumpet is blown, until they all fall dead. This is what is meant by the word of Allah in this verse."

It is narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah r.a. that the Messenger of Allah (saw) said:

"The Day of Resurrection will indeed occur when two people are spreading out their clothes (while bargaining), and they will not have time to buy and sell and fold them back. The Day of Resurrection will indeed occur when someone is making a pool and he has not had time to give a drink from that pool. The Day of Resurrection will indeed occur when someone is milking his goat and he has not had time to drink it, and the Day of Resurrection will indeed occur when someone is raising food to put it in his mouth, and he has not had time to eat it." (Narrated by al-Bukhari, Muslim from Abu Hurairah)
text.50: So swift was the coming of that event, and so sudden, that they had not the slightest opportunity to make a will or leave a message to their families, nor could they return to gather with them. Each faced his own problem, awaiting the judgment from the court of God, the Most Just and Almighty.
text.51:
After all of humanity has died with the first blowing of the trumpet, the second trumpet will then be blown to resurrect them from their graves. At that time, all of humanity will rise and come back to life. They will awaken and hasten to meet Allah Almighty to receive their reckoning (hisab).

Another verse related to this verse is the word of Allah:

(It will be) the Day when they will emerge from the graves quickly as if they were rushing to [their] idols. (al-Ma'arij/70: 43)
text.52:
This verse explains the astonishment and shock of the disbelievers when they are resurrected from their graves. They will say, "Woe to us! Who has raised us up from our sleeping place?" They are astonished and stunned because they are resurrected from the realm of the grave and face disaster and hardship at that time.

When they are astonished and stunned, among the believers will say to them, "All that is happening and that we are experiencing is in accordance with what Allah promised and was conveyed by the messengers who were sent to us all when we were in the world. We were told about the promise, the threat, and the Day of Resurrection like what we are facing now. Therefore, we should not be surprised and astonished by the situation we are experiencing now."

According to a narration, what is meant by the sound of the trumpet in this verse is the very loud voice of the angel Israfil proclaiming, "O bones that have been completely destroyed, Allah commands you all to gather again as before to receive a just decision."

In this verse, the disbelievers ask about who resurrected and revived them on this Day of Resurrection. Their question is answered with what was conveyed to them in the past when they were still alive in the world. This gives the understanding that it is as if Allah is telling them to remember what they did in the past to the messengers who were sent.
text.53:
This verse explains how easy it is for Allah to resurrect all of humanity who have ever existed before the Day of Judgment arrives. With just a single shout, all of humanity will come back to life and gather before Allah to receive a fair reckoning and judgment from Him.

Another verse with the same meaning as this verse is His saying:

"And the matter of the Hour is not but as a twinkle of the eye or even nearer. Indeed, Allah is over all things competent." (an-Nahl/16: 77)

And His saying:

"It will be only a single blast, and at once they will be upon the earth alive." (an-Nazi'at/79: 13-14)
text.54: Then Allah explains that on the Day of Judgment, every human being will receive the recompense for all the deeds they have done during their life in the world. Good deeds will be rewarded with manifold rewards, and bad and evil deeds will be punished with a punishment commensurate with the deed. Just as it is Allah's attribute to give judgment with justice, on that day He will also give judgment with justice. Therefore, a person will not receive the reward for the good deeds done by others, and conversely, a person will not receive punishment for the evil deeds done by others.
text.55: Allah explains that those who believe will be rewarded by Allah with manifold rewards, in the form of Paradise full of delights. In it, they will experience pleasures and enjoyments they have never felt before, beauty they have never seen, and soothing sounds that have never been heard. At that time, they will not think about the torment being suffered by the disbelievers who are immersed in Hell. What they feel and remember is only joy and contentment with their companions in Paradise.
text.56:
In Paradise, the believers and their spouses will be in beautiful gardens with shady trees, sitting on sofas and beds, conversing while enjoying the various provisions they receive from their Lord.

From the phrase "hum wa azwajuhum" (they and their spouses), it can be understood that the believers will live with their spouses happily and peacefully in Paradise, obtaining unparalleled blessings in various forms. Some are enjoyed directly, such as obtaining comfortable and beautiful places, as well as experiencing delicious food and so on. Others are in the form of fulfilling their desires and aspirations as members or heads of families. During their lives in the world, they aspired to happy families, having beautiful and faithful wives. Such desires of theirs will be fulfilled by Allah in Paradise.

In fact, in another verse it is explained that their believing descendants will be elevated by Allah to the same rank as their parents. They will be gathered with their parents in Paradise, without differentiating the bestowal of blessings to each family member. Allah says:

"And those who believe and whose descendants follow them in faith - We will join with them their descendants, and We will not deprive them of anything of their deeds. Every person, for what he earned, is retained." (ath-Thur/52: 21)

From this verse, it is also understood that every believer should always strive to make their husband, wife, children, and family good believers, so that their aspirations to be able to connect with their families will be granted by Allah in the Hereafter.
text.57:
Those who believe will eat various delicious fruits in Paradise, and obtain everything they desire. For those who like to play, various games are provided, and for those who like sports, all sports needs are also provided. Likewise, all the art tools they desire. Allah says:

*Within it they can call for every [kind of] fruit - safe and secure.* (ad-Dukhan/44: 55)

(58) What they desire is a greeting of peace from Allah conveyed to them to honor them. This greeting is conveyed directly by Allah or perhaps through the mediation of angels, as Allah says:

*And the angels will enter upon them from every gate, [saying], "Peace be upon you for what you patiently endured." And excellent is the final home.* (ar-Ra'd/13: 23-24)

Salam means safety and well-being, protected from everything undesirable, obtaining everything desired, so that the person obtains physical and spiritual pleasures that are unparalleled.

text.59:
Allah commands the disbelievers to immediately separate themselves from the believers and enter Hell, a place prepared for them.

This command is conveyed by Allah after all of humanity has finished being reckoned in the Gathering Place (Padang Mahsyar). The believers are commanded to enter Paradise, and the disbelievers are commanded to enter Hell.

Another verse with a similar meaning to this verse is the word of Allah:

(It will be commanded to the angels), "Assemble those who wronged, together with their peers and what they used to worship other than Allah, and guide them to the way to hell." (ash-shaffat/37: 22-23)
text.60:
In this verse, it is explained that the disbelievers who are driven into hell are rebuked and reminded by Allah of the sinful deeds they committed in the world. Allah says, "Did I not enjoin upon you, O children of Adam, that you should not worship Satan? And I presented to you strong evidence according to reason, and I sent messengers to you carrying books containing guidance to the path of happiness in this world and the hereafter. In fact, with the guidance and the sending of messengers, it was sufficient reason for you not to follow the temptations of Satan. But you ignored all of that, so your fate is as it is now."

Allah explains His reason for forbidding humans from following Satan, which is because Satan is a clear enemy to mankind. The enmity between humans and Satan has been going on since ancient times, namely since Satan misled Adam and Eve, so that Allah expelled them from Paradise. Since then, Satan has always strived and endeavored to mislead mankind.
text.61: Allah commands mankind to worship Him alone, to follow all that He has commanded, and to cease all that He has forbidden. If a person has carried out all that He has commanded and ceased all that He has forbidden, then he has traversed the path that is pleasing to Him, and that is the straight path and that is the true religion that originates from the Lord of the universe.
text.62:
This verse explains the influence and consequences of Satan's temptations on humans, which is that they disbelieve and disobey Allah, and indeed many among them associate partners with Him.

How weak are the hearts of humans, that they can be tempted by Satan. Even though they have been endowed with intellect, thought, feelings, physical and spiritual abilities, as well as *taufik* and *hidayah* in the form of the religion conveyed to them by the Messenger. In truth, with all the blessings given, humans can distinguish between what is right and what is wrong, which is the straight path and which is the path of error, which are sinful deeds and which are righteous deeds. But they are negligent and always follow their desires.
text.63: Allah declares to the disbelievers, "O you disbelievers, this is Hell Jahannam which I promised you, and that promise was conveyed by the messenger who was sent to you during your life in the world. However, you did not believe it, rather you denied and disobeyed Me and worshipped gods besides Me." The Qur'an uses the word *hadzihi*, which is a form of *isim isyarah* (demonstrative pronoun) for something near, to depict that Hell Jahannam is already before them; this is a terrifying image.
text.64:
Furthermore, Allah commands them, "O disbelievers, enter and taste on this day the heat of Hellfire. Remain in it as a recompense for the disbelief and sinful deeds that you committed before."

From these verses, it is understood as if Allah is warning the disbelievers who are being punished that they no longer need to regret, despair, and grieve because of the punishment they are experiencing. The punishment given to them is a divine decree that cannot be changed. They were given various warnings and various trials while they were alive in the world, but they remained in denial. Therefore, feel and accept the punishment that is being inflicted.
text.65:
When receiving punishment in hell, some of the disbelievers will deny their evil deeds in the world, as explained in Allah's word:

Then their only excuse will be to say, "By Allah, our Lord, we were not polytheists." (al-An'am/6: 23)

So, in verse 65, Allah seals their mouths shut so that they cannot lie or dispute the existence of their deeds. Moreover, their hands will then speak and their feet will bear witness to what they did, so they can no longer deny their actions against religion. On the Day of Judgment, justice will be applied fairly according to all their deeds in the world.

According to a narration from Anas bin Malik, he said: From Anas bin Malik, he said, "We were with the Prophet saw, and suddenly he laughed. He said, "Do you know why I am laughing?" We replied, "Allah and His Messenger know best." He said, "(I am laughing) because of the conversation between a servant and his Lord." The servant said, "O my Lord, did You not save me from injustice?" "Yes, indeed, I saved you," his Lord replied. The servant said, "Indeed, I will not allow anyone to testify against myself except a witness from myself." His Lord replied, "Enough, you are a witness against yourself, and the angels recording deeds are also witnesses." The Prophet saw then said, "Then the servant's mouth was sealed, and the limbs were ordered to speak, "Speak!" The Prophet saw added, "Then the limbs spoke (according to their deeds)." (Narrated by Imam Abu Ya'la al-Maushuli)

Many verses of the Qur'an explain the testimony of human body parts regarding the actions they have committed during their lives in this world, including Allah's word:

On the Day when their tongues, their hands, and their feet will bear witness against them as to what they used to do. (an-Nur/24: 24)

Allah makes hands and feet speak as witnesses because the hands are the ones that perform the actions, while the feet witness what the hands do. So, the action of the hand is an affirmation or confession, while the words of the feet are a testimony.

If all the bad deeds of a person are revealed and exposed during their life in the world and known by many people, then they feel ashamed and find it difficult to hide their faces. In fact, many people commit suicide because they cannot bear the shame. In the Hereafter, they will experience what they could not experience and bear during their life in the world.
text.66: This verse explains Allah's power over His servants, that if He willed, He could erase the sight and hearing of the disbelievers, so they would be unable to see even though they should be doing many good deeds. However, because of Allah's compassion for mankind, He does not do that. The disbelievers are still able to see and do good in the world according to religious guidance. However, they do not do that; instead, they commit many sins. Thus, besides not having good deeds that deserve reward, their sins are also very numerous, so Allah's punishment in the Hereafter will certainly be very severe. They cannot escape all of that because of the testimony of their hands and feet.
text.67: This verse also explains Allah's power, which is that if Allah wills, He can change the form of the disbelievers in the places where they are, so that they are no longer able to walk and return. However, this is not done because Allah is the Most Compassionate and Most Merciful. Even so, the disbelievers who have the opportunity to perform righteous deeds according to religious guidance do not do so; in fact, they increase in disbelief, making them worthy of a severe and humiliating punishment in the Hereafter.
text.68:
Furthermore, Allah affirms that whoever has their life prolonged will surely be returned to the beginning of their creation. Meaning, they return to being weak and lacking intellect like a small child. They are no longer strong enough to perform arduous acts of worship and begin to forget much, so they cannot perform worship well. At the end of this verse, Allah questions why they do not understand and use the opportunity while they are still young and strong.

The Prophet (saw) explained this in his hadith which reads:

"Take advantage of five things before five others: your free time before your busyness, your wealth before your poverty, your health before your sickness, your youth before your old age, and your life before your death." (Narrated by al-Hakim from Ibn 'Abbas)

Do the disbelievers not use their minds that the longer and older a person's life becomes, the weaker their physical and spiritual state becomes, and the less able they are to act? Allah has given them enough life to be able to do much, perform righteous deeds, seek sufficient knowledge, worship well, and so on. However, they do not use that life in the best possible way. Allah sent messengers to them bringing guidance to the straight path, but they did not follow the messengers and that guidance; instead, they denied and rejected it.
text.69:
In this verse, Allah refutes the accusations of the disbelievers who said that the Qur'an was poetry created by the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) himself. Thus, according to their accusations, Muhammad was a poet. This is strongly refuted in this verse, because the Qur'an is a revelation from Allah that brings the truth. And the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was tasked with conveying to mankind all the truth he received from Allah. The Prophet Muhammad is not a poet who only imagines, but a messenger of Allah who brings the truth to correct the people of ignorance (jahiliyyah).

The Qur'an is very different from the poetry that developed in the Arabian lands at that time. The differences can be seen in the following:

1.  Arab poetry at that time was a series of sentences bound by *wazan* (sentence meter) or certain patterns, certain *bahr-bahr* (rhythm and notation in Arabic poetry), such as *bahr kamil*, *bahr rajaz*, and others.

    Meanwhile, the verses of the Qur'an have such beautiful sentence structures, the choice of words is so precise, but it is not bound by the *wazan* and *bahr* of Arabic poetry.

2.  Arab poetry is also bound by *qafiyah*, which is a certain final letter. If this is not fulfilled, then the poem is ruined, so there is an element of coercion or *takalluf*.

    In the verses of the Qur'an, there are indeed several identical final letters that rhyme (*masju'*), but it becomes more beautiful because it is not rigid and there is no element of coercion (*takalluf*).

3.  The content of Arab poetry is usually the poet's imagination with high imagination, so that it forgets many things that are not in accordance with reality.

    Meanwhile, the verses of the Qur'an are all in accordance with reality, both the unseen and the real world, thus providing correct information.

4.  Arab poems usually consist of excessive praise for the king or tribal chief, which makes the kings more arrogant. Poetry can also contain insults or ridicule towards enemies, thus increasing existing hostility.

    Meanwhile, the Qur'an always speaks of the truth without making people arrogant, in fact the verses of the Qur'an forbid arrogance and feelings of hatred and hostility.

5.  Arab poems are often composed and arranged by poets and used to get gifts as a poet's livelihood.

    Meanwhile, the verses of the Qur'an solely provide information, guidance, and good lessons. In fact, the verses of the Qur'an must not be sold cheaply to obtain certain income.

From the above, it is proven that the language of the Qur'an is more beautiful than poetry and its content is better and provides greater benefits for human life as a whole.

Allah affirms that He did not teach poetry to Muhammad (peace be upon him). He only revealed the Qur'an to him, to be conveyed to mankind. The accusations of the polytheists and disbelievers that Muhammad (peace be upon him) was a poet are inappropriate accusations and unacceptable to a sound mind.

Then Allah affirms again that the Qur'an conveyed by Muhammad (peace be upon him) is a lesson and a holy book that provides enlightenment to mankind to achieve inner and outer happiness, in this world and the hereafter.

The polytheists say that the Qur'an is poetry, because the words and sentences contained in it are so beautiful and precise. Sometimes they even say that the Qur'an is magic, because the words and sentence structure are indeed mesmerizing to anyone who hears it. However, their accusations are completely untrue. The Qur'an is neither magic nor poetry, because poetry is a structure that is bound to certain patterns, while the Qur'an is not.
text.70:
Furthermore, Allah explains that one of the functions of the Qur'an is to provide a warning to humankind. In addition to that, it also clarifies the certainty of a decreed punishment for the disbelievers.

Those whose hearts, minds, and spirits remain alive will surely take the Qur'an as their primary guide, because the Qur'an brings teachings that eliminate ignorance and stagnation, heal mental illnesses that damage human life, both outwardly and inwardly, and become a mercy for those who are pious.

Conversely, those whose hearts, minds, and spirits are already dead and frozen, do not want to take lessons and guidance from the Qur'an because the temptations of Satan have shackled them so severely.

In reality, in the hearts of the leaders of the disbelieving and polytheistic people, they have acknowledged the truth and miraculous nature of the Qur'an. However, they do not dare to express this acknowledgment, because they fear losing influence within their community, which would cause a decline in their authority and loss of their source of income.
text.71:
